title: Drug dealer hid wraps of heroin and cash inside his prosthetic leg
text:
Mohamed Abdi-Hassan (left) and Reagan Pires have been jailed for flooding the streets of Swindon, Wiltshire, with Class A drugs (Picture: Wiltshire Police)

A drug dealer has been jailed for three years and ten months after being caught with drugs and cash inside his prosthetic leg.

Mohamed Abdi-Hassan, 29, helped flood the town of Swindon with heroin and crack cocaine worth almost £100,000.

He was arrested in September 2016 and found with 47 drugs wraps and almost £300 in cash stashed inside his prosthetic limb.

Abdi-Hassan, of Leicester, lost his left foot and much of his right leg in successive road accidents.

His lawyer appealed for a non-custodial sentence, telling the judge that he struggled with his mobility in prison.

But judge Jason Taylor QC jailed Abdi-Hassan and his co-defendant Reagan Pires for conspiracy to supply drugs in the Wiltshire town.

Mohammed Abdi-Hassan tried to avoid justice by hiding his stash of drugs and money in his prosthetic leg (Picture: Wiltshire Police)

Swindon Crown Court was told that the pair were part of the Santana County Line drugs gang, based in London.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Over a 14 month period in 2016 and 2017, the gang had sold £95,000-worth of class A drugs in Swindon – the equivalent of more than 10,000 drug deals.

Prosecutors said the pair sent out thousands of texts to advertise their drugs to known addicts.

They would then use runners as young as 15 to deliver them.

The pair were linked to the crimes by telephone records and when they were arrested, they were found in possession of the drugs.

Pires was arrested in February 2016 and found with 16 wraps of heroin and crack cocaine, £295 in cash, and two phones which contained contacts with the Santana drugs line.

A month after his arrest, he was picked up in an alleyway with another suspected member of the conspiracy.

Abdi-Hassan was first arrested at a house in Swindon in September 2016.

He was subsequently arrested a further twice within the next four weeks.

On all occasions, he had a phone with him that showed significant contact with the Santana drugs gang.

Reagan Pires was 19 years old when he got caught up in the London-based drug gang (Picture: Wiltshire Police)

Puneet Grewal, representing Pires, said her client’s involvement in the conspiracy was very limited.

He was 19 years old at the time, had dropped out of college, been smoking cannabis and had got involved with the wrong crowd.

Pires was said to be extremely remorseful, saying the impact of his criminal behaviour on his family had torn him apart.

Defending Abdi-Hassan, Gareth James asked that his client be spared jail as he had struggled during a year behind bars waiting for the case to go to Crown Court.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Pires was jailed for three years and four months.

Judge Taylor told them: ‘This was a conspiracy to supply class A drugs and the message must go out that it can’t be tolerated.’

Earlier this month, police arrested more than 60 people across Swindon and north Wiltshire in a concerted push against County Lines gangs.

The city-based groups have largely cornered the heroin and crack market in smaller cities and towns.

They typically use vulnerable addicts or children as runners, sending them hundreds of miles across the country to sell drugs.

Det Insp Paul Franklin of Wiltshire Police’s dedicated crime team said: ‘Our message to any drug gang in Swindon and Wiltshire is that we are not a soft touch and you are not welcome here – if we find you, we will arrest you.’
